answer_html: valid when \(\displaystyle |2x| <1\), that is, when \(\displaystyle |x|<1/2\).
hints_html:
Recall the geometric series summation given by

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1-x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}x^{n}\end{aligned}\]

valid when \(\displaystyle |x|<1\)
question: 1 (k)
sols_html:
We proceed by using the geometric series summation given by

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{1-x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}x^{n}\end{aligned}\]

valid for \(|x|<1\). To mimic this, we proceed via

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2x-1} &= -\frac{1}{1-2x}\\ &= -\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(2x)^{n}\end{aligned}\]

valid when \(\displaystyle |2x| <1\), that is, when \(\displaystyle |x|<1/2\).
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Put your answer in the box provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Find the Maclaurin series for \(\displaystyle f(x) = \frac{1}{2x - 1}\) .
